fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Monad container distributive laws allow you to define a notion of composition for monad containers. They are in bijection with compatible compositions of monad containers.

Let (S \triangleleft P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleleft Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers, where S \triangleleft P satisfies S3 (for s, f) and the singleton properties, and T \triangleleft Q has a constant t_0.
We start by assuming a monad container distributive law of type S \triangleleft P \circ T \triangleleft Q \Rightarrow T \triangleleft Q \circ S \triangleleft P .
For a shape s : S and function f : P\ s \to S that satisfy S3, and a constant t_0 : T, we have for any p : P\ s the equality: u_1\ s\ t_0^p = t_0

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
By the chain of equalities:
\begin {align*} &u_1\ s\ t_0^p\\ &= u_1\ s\ (\lambda p' . \begin {cases} u_1\ \iota ^S\ (\lambda \_ . t_0) & \text {if } p' = p\\ u_1\ (f\ p')\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ^T) & \text {otherwise} \end {cases})\\ &= u_1\ s\ (\lambda p' . u_1\ (\begin {cases} \iota ^S & \text {if } p' = p\\ f\ p' & \text {otherwise} \end {cases})\ (\lambda \_ . \begin {cases} t_0 & \text {if } p' = p\\ \iota ^T & \text {otherwise} \end {cases}))\\ &= u_1\ (\sigma ^S\ s\ (\lambda p' . \begin {cases} \iota ^S & \text {if } p' = p\\ f\ p' & \text {otherwise} \end {cases}))\ (\lambda p'' . \begin {cases} t_0 & \text {if } \text {pr}^S_1\ p'' = p\\ \iota ^T & \text {otherwise} \end {cases})\\ &\overset {(S3)}{=} u_1\ \iota ^S\ (\lambda \_ . \begin {cases} t_0 & \text {if } * = *\\ \iota ^T & \text {otherwise} \end {cases})\\ &= t_0 \end {align*}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a shape s : S and function f : P\ s \to S that satisfy S3, where s has at least two positions p, p' : P\ s, then T cannot have more than one distinct constant shape.

This gives us a family of no-go theorems for distributive laws between monad containers. This theorem and proof is morally the same as the one in [zwartmarsden2022] of the same name, but it applies to a different class of monads (ones isomorphic to the extension of a monad container).

fr:title.text: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These are mostly inspired by Zwart and Marsden's research into no-go theorems for distributive laws between algebraic theories [zwartmarsden2022].

I've been roughly translating properties of algebraic theories into the language of monad containers (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}), by considering:
Shapes s : S as "terms"
Positions p : P\ s as "free variables in the term s"
\iota as a "generic variable placeholder"
\sigma as a "generalised substitution"
\text {pr} as a "reindexing" of positions after a "substitution" This is not meant to be an exact translation; the idea is to get inspiration for properties of monad containers we might want to consider when proving things about monad container distributive laws.
(S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) satisfies the singleton property if P\ \iota \cong 1. All cartesian monad containers have this property by definition.

A property of algebraic theories that is used implicitly in [zwartmarsden2022] is commutativity of disjoint substitutions, i.e. given terms s, s_0 and a substitution f where for all y, x 
otin 	ext {var}(f(y)) we always have that: s[s_0/x][f(y) / y 
eq x] = s[f(y) / y 
eq x][s_0/x]

The List monad container \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} satisfies this, which makes sense since it can also be represented by an algebraic theory. This also holds for coproduct, reader (trivially), state, writer, and probably many others!
EDIT: In fact, this holds for all monad containers, and the proof is quite simple (just use associativity of \sigma and "pull the case distinctions through the inner \sigma ").
(S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) has a constant shape if there exists some s_0 : S where P\ s_0 \cong 0.

Notice that all functions P\ s_0 \to S are equal to \lambda \_ . \iota , since P\ s_0 is propositional and pointed (and therefore contractible). As a consequence of this, we have that: \sigma \ s_0\ f = \sigma \ s_0\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) = s_0

This holds for \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} for example: take n to be any natural number greater than 0, take f := \lambda \_ . 0, and then given some x : \text {Fin}\ n we have \sum _{i = 0}^{n} f^x\ i = 1. Notice that this property holds for all n with non-empty position sets, so \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} actually satisfies a stronger condition (analogous to Zwart and Marsden's S4 [zwartmarsden2022]).
This also holds for state, by taking s = \text {id} and f = \lambda \_ . \text {id}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container distributive law from compatible composite

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let (S \triangleleft P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleleft Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers and (\sigma , \text {pr}) be a compatible composite of these monad containers (of type T \triangleleft Q \circ S \triangleleft P). We can define a monad container distributive law (of type S \triangleleft P \circ T \triangleleft Q \Rightarrow T \triangleleft Q \circ S \triangleleft P) as follows:
\begin {align*} u\ s\ f &:= \sigma \ (\iota ^T, \lambda \_ . s)\ (\lambda p . (f\ (\pi _2\ p), \lambda \_ . \iota ^S))\\ v\ q\ p &:= (\pi _2\ (\text {pr}_1\ (q , p)) , \pi _1\ (\text {pr}_2\ (q , p))) \end {align*}

Following an idea Stef and I had a couple months ago, I'm going to specialse monad container distributive laws to the case where v = \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simple examples.

Essentially by adopting v = \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , all of the position equalities become trivial, and we are just left with shape equalities (with no mention of v). Hopefully it will be easier to prove things in this simpler case!

fr:title.text: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As mentioned in [ahmanuustalu2013], directed container distributive laws are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions. Further, composition of directed containers via a distributive law is a generalisation of the Zappa-Szép product of two monoids. As mentioned in the paper, you can actually recover the definition of a matching pair by looking at distributive laws between representable directed containers.

fr:title.text: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As it turns out, monad container distributive laws are also a generalisation of matching pairs of monoid actions. This is a bit harder to see than in the directed container case, but as before we can recover the data and equations for a matching pair by specialising the distributive law to a particular type of monad container.

fr:title.text: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As shown, both of these types of distributive law are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions, each in a slightly different way. For directed containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the shapes", and for monad containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the positions".
Edit (29/01/25): we also get that (monad-comonad) mixed container distributive laws correspond to matching pairs of monoid actions when specialised to a particular pair of containers:

fr:title.text: Monad-comonad container distributive law between writer monad and coreader comonad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad-comonad container distributive law between writer monad and coreader comonad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: It should be possible to use this to define some kind of monoid bimodules (bialgebras), given that monad-comonad distributive laws are used in the literature [livernetetal2015] to define a "bi-Eilenberg-Moore" category.
Strangely, comonad-monad container distributive laws seem to break this pattern, and do not give us matching pairs of monoid maps when specialising them to particular containers:

fr:title.text: Comonad-monad container distributive law between coreader comonad and writer monad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Comonad-monad container distributive law between coreader comonad and writer monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This doesn't seem to correspond to anything that I've heard of, and certainly doesn't look like a matching pair of monoid actions, in particular since the first argument of \alpha is a function.
We should be able to define something that looks like a two sided Kleisli category with this.

fr:title.text: Coproduct monad container distribution on the left

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coproduct monad container distribution on the left

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
The coproduct monad container 1 + E \triangleleft T distributes over any monad container S \triangleleft P in exactly one way.
917#263unstable-263.xmlProof20241210Chris Purdy We have given the first 4 equations for a monad container distributive law and the isomorphisms T\ (\text {inl}\ *) \to S \cong S and T\ (\text {inr}\ e) \to S \cong 1 that: \begin {align*} &u\ (\text {inl}\ *)\ (\lambda \_ . s) = (s , \lambda \_ . \text {inl}\ *)\\ &u\ (\text {inr}\ e)\ f = u\ (\text {inr}\ e)\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ^S) = (\iota ^S , \lambda \_ . \text {inr}\ e)\\ &v\ \{\text {inl}\ *\}\ \{\lambda \_ . s\}\ (p , *) = (* , p) \end {align*} These constraints entirely define u, and therefore v also. Since the other distributive law equalities hold, u and v specify the unique distributive law (1 + E \triangleleft T) \circ (S \triangleleft P) \Rightarrow (S \triangleleft P) \circ (1 + E \triangleleft T).

fr:title.text: Representable monad container distribution on the right

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Representable monad container distribution on the right

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Any monad container S \triangleleft P distributes over a representable monad container 1 \triangleleft \lambda \_ . A in exactly one way.
977#264unstable-264.xmlProof2024125Chris Purdy By considering the data for a monad container distributive law, we get by the first four equalities, and for all s : S the isomorphism P\ s \to 1 \cong 1, that: \begin {align*} u\ s\ \_ &:= (* , \lambda \_ . s)\\ v\ p\ a &:= (a , p) \end {align*} u and v are entirely specified by the "unit" equalities, and the rest of the equalities hold. Hence this is the unique monad distributive law of S \triangleleft P over 1 \triangleleft \lambda \_ . A.

fr:title.text: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monad T is idempotent when T \eta = \eta T, which for monad containers immediately gives us \iota = s for all s : S, and hence S is contractible.

Another equivalent condition for a monad T to be idempotent is that \text {Id} is a distributive law TT \Rightarrow TT. For monad container distributive laws this implies futher that all positions are equal, so the set P\ \iota is subsingleton.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as \mathbf {Set} functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
